title: Raw undeveloped idea for behavior
body:
If you got this far... What if there were a by default silenced channel in game ...

The Trash Chat.

So then you'd have PMs, system messages, ally chat, all chat, and then trash chat. Can only opt into trash chat voluntarily. Only the Insta-ban stuff is not allowed in trash talk (racism, suicide encouragement, etc). Looks like

Zed (2gud4u) Trash: lol u popped so ez

Then flame away.

replies.body:
The issue isn't that Riot hasn't found a way to allow trash talk, they just don't want it on their platform.

 Like yeah, it would work and it would be a decent solution to help curb some repeat offenders or people who enjoy it, but ultimately Riot chooses not to do it because they don't want to promote or encourage that behavior.

Indeed would not expect Riot to do anything for the player's sake. It appears Riot's position is to look like they're addressing the toxicity while having given up on actually doing something about it. The current system has been black and white for years and it's breeding new kinds of toxic behaviors. I can't think of a kinder way to put it...

This probably would help though, and if in a couple years someone is actually going to reform the punishments, something like this discussion might help.

Why do you say it would help, though?

Riot doesn't allow trash talk because from their internal data and survey responses: People who are exposed to trash talk spend less money on skins, play fewer games per session, and play less frequently.

Trash talk is already allowed, as long as it doesn't cross the line. Problem is, people are always trying to move the line.

It's worth noting that Riot says the vast majority of the player base not only uses chat  appropriately, but in a way that is pretty much indistinguishable from being under a chat restriction. That is, they use a greeting, say "GG" at the end and maybe a couple of things during the match. That being the case, there's no real point to Riot creating a special place for people to indulge their worst impulses. There aren't enough people who would use it and many of those that did wouldn't accept that there would still be restrictions within that channel.
Have the numbers and tracking always been that way, or is this recent data? My perception is that more players used to chat more.

But why not? There's not really other places on the interwebz to indulge such things. LOL :D{{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}

This reminds me of the Prisoner's Island idea, which Riot is against. Yes this would be opt-in but why make something like that when players could just be mature and responsible and not flame others for X reason? Also, it's no longer trash talk if you're just talking like trash. At the end of the day Riot is not a babysitter, and players need to take responsibility for their actions rather than look for ways to abuse and harass others consequence free, which is what this idea sounds like it's for (yes I know you said ZTP stuff wouldn't be allowed but that's beside the point). This is a game, not a venting platform.

With respect, this sounds exclusionary to other mindsets that aren't looking to abuse people and just want to let out frustration. Believe me, most people don't want to do that- but I'm betting most wouldn't mind the ability to call out dumb.
Riot is a host, and as a host demanding player's near full attention for up to about an hour at a time, should do what they can to take care of its needs. It is a competitive game cheifly about killing, not a peaceful, casual, cooperative one. As you said, Riot is not a babysitter...
And yet here we are with Happyland expectation for chat.

I'll spare the happyland comments when you take it seriously and not look at it as a way for the bad eggs to be bad.

But I'll use the "this is a game, not a venting platform" comment the next time I see someone venting in game. That will not go over well. Because League *is* a way to vent, intentionally designed that way or not. Okay, Please pay attention here v

Players often get angry in League. Winning is most intensely rewarding- in other words, the most intense moments that cause addiction- when having gotten angry in the match and the player's focus and problem solving contributed to victory. However, to get the fullest satisfaction from this, a person needs to get past the frustration and move on to the problem solving part. Sometimes, league is frustration. The build isn't working. The support is working against me. Their JG is oppressing me. My team isn't grouping for a teamfight. The chance to problem solve isn't being given, and the ability to use anger productively is being denied. Getting denied the true purpose of playing the game in the first place, many deflate, retaliate destructively... aka tilt.

Give PEOPLE a way to release their anger non-destructively. We're not machines that will stop making anger juice because of forced repression.

Edit: this isn't a demand that Riot do it. I think Riot isn't doing the best it could, and by discussing it instead of saying "riot won't do that", what adjustments might be a better way? Is a channel for venting really a bad idea?
So what's the problem space you are trying to tackle and how does your solution solve the problem?

I don't know if "problem space" is a term for something specific or otherwise, I'll presume it is not.

The problem is some folks are playing League to vent. That is, to work out their anger. The game itself sometimes causes anger- either from expectations being broken, or other player's behavior. Some are external to league but still associated with the action of playing League- "Husband, it is trash night, did you take out the trash?" "Yeah, yeah, I'll get it!" Etc.

It is not kind to restrict communication to strictly be positive and relevant to the game. People are expected to deal with their own anger, yes, but in game you are actively interacting with others and even pausing 10 seconds to take a deep breath could be worse than...

Lee (xmas) Trash: "Damn it, you really screwed that up"

See the solution and problem now?

"Problem space" is a general design terminology where you define something as a problem that needs to be improved upon, then your goal is to improve on that problem. 

If we use [WuKong's gameplay update](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/vbh0QVyZ-wukong-update-prepped-for-pbe) as example, one of the problem spaces was that his passive felt underwhelming and unappreciated. So the designer would have to come up with something to make his passive feels powerful and interactive. 

From an in-game design perspective, this problem space can be solved through the change of mechanics, change of visual effects, change of sound effects or a combination of everything. In this case, the designer opted to use the change of mechanics and a visual effect to tackle the problem space. Whether it hits the mark is another question.

In design, it's a good habit to constantly remind yourself of the problem space you are trying to solve. Having a clear problem statement or a well defined problem space will help keep you on track in designing good solutions. Keep in mind that the problem space you are trying to solve should align with entity's values, else you'll end up designing something that the entity feels is wrong and won't further explore your design.

So if I'm reading you correctly,  the problem space you are trying to solve is to ... reduce anger from the game? And your solution is to create an opt-in flame channel that allows people to flame without others seeing it?

In a sense, the game already has a similar feature. You can type something and press ESC to cancel what you typed, or you can use /n (aka /note) to type stuff that only you can see. It will even be saved into a txt file where you can open in notepad later.

If that's not the problem space you are trying to solve, or the current solution is not something you are satisfied with, then you'd have to redefine the problem space to further understand what you are trying to solve and why the current solution is not working.

Understood!

Specifically, the problem I'm pointing at: players do not have an in-game way to vent in a way that does not cause other problems.

Due to the nature of the game, a player is required to be operating with nearly full attention on the game- incidentally, my example earlier demonstrates that outside factors often can cause stress because it is distracting. Due to this, if a player needs to vent (and many do this intuitively rather than consciously), they must do so while playing the game. The time after death offers some reprieve, but that's only sometimes good enough.

Incidentally, some opt to not vent at all while playing. While this spares other players from unreasonable fury, not dealing with anger is unhealthy. I expect players going through that are not encouraged to buy skins etc.

Allowing players to vent in a chat in which the ones they're interacting with can be a solution....

Edit, resuming.

...with the possibility of the venting resulting in problem solving help from allies or even kind enemies. From an individualistic viewpoint, venting leads to stronger problem solving ability and greater focus toward goals. Collectively, verbal venting raises awareness of problems and *can mitigate or even eliminate negativity*. I'd love to link a study or two on that in different environments but I'm on my phone. Of course, there can be negative consequences if allowed to be rampant...
Which gives me the idea to limit how much one can chat with a certain time in said chat...
...but if the channel is labeled trash chat, it stays in trash, with the explicit expectation of it being toxic.

I believe people have attempted to stop toxicity, and I think they were looking at the problem wrong. You can't stop toxic.

But you can work with it.

2nd edit: it's not intended to be invisible flailing, but invisible to those who don't want to see it. i do the would be flames when I'm at my worst and hit esc... I thought that was a weird habbit!

If players want to vent they can do so in ways that don't involve the use of chat, such as yelling at the screen, punching a pillow or squeezing a stress ball. If they have to vent through text then they can use Notepad or a Word document or something. There are plenty of options available to do so, but LoL isn't and shouldn't be one of them. Rather than trying to give these players an outlet to vent in the game (and thus be essentially immune to any major consequences) we should instead at the very least encourage them to vent elsewhere if need be. Again this is a game, not a venting platform, and there's no need to cater to those who can't or won't control themselves for the duration of the game.
I wish they would try to help a little. I can feel people's frustration and I wish someone would help.
Nah. If it was anything goes, I'd support it. But you still want there to be rules for the trash chat channel.
